item.title: Agrotis ipsilon
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Agrotis ipsilon (Hufnagel)

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Holometabola, Lepidoptera, Noctuidae.

Common name: Black cutworm.

Geographical distribution: Almost cosmopolitan, Commonwealth Institute of Entomology Map #261, 1969.

Host plants: Seedlings of most crops, including legumes, crucifers, Solanaceae and cotton in the Middle East.

Economic importance: Larvae commonly feed on seedlings, cutting off their stems at ground level, which topples them. Additionally, the larvae may feed on roots, thus occasionally causing great damage in newly planted fields (e.g. cotton) early in the season.

Morphology: The specific name of the pest (ipsilon) derives from the markings on the adult forewing, which resemble the Greek character “ipsilon”. Its common name (“cutworm”) is due to the nature of the damage, the cutting off of seedlings at ground level, and the dark background coloration of the larval integument.

Life cycle: Female adults, which are reproductively immature on emergence, begin oviposition within a week and survive for about another week. During their gravid period eggs are deposited singly or in small clusters, on the underside of leaves, near ground level. A female may lay up to 1900 eggs during its lifetime. The larvae disperse after the first molt and remain solitary for the rest of their lives, residing in the soil during day, coming up to feed at night.

Seasonal history: The pest is a migratory species, with no seasonal diapause. The duration of each generation is one-two months, depending on environmental conditions. In Israel the pest has 4-5 generations, of which those with most potential to cause damage are during autumn (November-December) and spring (February-March). Early autumn rains (e.g. high humidity) and mild temperatures are conducive to population increase. The autumn population in Israel is presumably bolstered by migrant adults. Infestations in Syria are higher in years with high rainfall.

Management

The occasional appearance of black cutworm populations poses a logistic problem for preventive measures, especially as the larvae reside in the soil, making detection difficult until damage had revealed their existence. Control measures are difficult because of the inaccessible location of the larvae to some forms of chemical applications. One preventive measure is sanitation, the removal of weeds and volunteer plants from previously-damaged fields and their surroundings, and deep ploughing if populations recur. Adults on the wing can be monitored by pheromone trapping. First damage may usually be expected about 2 weeks after peak flight.

Chemical control: Spray applications may be directed towards first instar larvae while they are still feeding on the underside of foliage, or else granular insecticides can be applied onto the soil. Moistened poison bait may be mixed with the organophosphates trichlofon and parathion, or the carbamate carbaryl, and broadcast in the field at 10 kg/ha, preferably in the evening.

Natural enemies: Natural enemies are not reliable for black cutworm control, mostly due to the sporadic appearance of the pest and the inability of seedlings to compensate for any incurred damage.

References

item.title: Aphytis chilensis
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphytis chilensis Howard

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Holometabola, Hymenoptera, Chalcidoidea, Aphelinidae.

Geographical distribution: Cosmopolitan.

Hosts: Several armored scale insects (Diaspididae).

Economic importance: An important parasitoid of the oleander scale, Aspidiotus nerii Bouche.

Morphology: The female is yellow, its size being from 0.5 to 1.1 mm; smaller specimens are paler, bear less setae and were even described as a separate species (Aphytis riadi).

Life cycle: Like other members of its genus, Aphytis chilensis is an ectoparasitoid of armored scale insects. The 2nd-stage nymphs, young females and scale prepupae are attacked, but the ovipositing females are the preferred stage for parasitization. The eggs are deposited through the shield onto the host’s body.

(Figure 1)

Due to the fact that at molting the shields of these insects adhere to their bodies, the parasitoid can deposit only between molts. Its emerging larvae feed on the scales and prior to pupation they excrete their fecal matter (meconia). The pupa is free, and its eyes change from colorless to red to green, providing an indication of its age. The adult often emerges through an exit hole in the shield, or by crawling out from underneath. Although reared (in the field and in the laboratory) from several hosts, it seems to prefer the oleander scale. Aphytis chilensis is thelytokous (but males have been described), requiring ca 18 days to complete a generation at 28Â°C and each female produces about 25 offspring. In the field the parasitoid has two population peaks, in spring and in autumn. It attacks mainly young host females and is a voracious host feeder, killing more scales by this practice than by parasitization.

Water extract of the shield of the oleander scale elicited a positive response from A. chilensis, suggesting that its host-searching is based on chemical cues.

References

item.title: Aphytis chrysomphali
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphytis chrysomphali (Mercet)

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Holometabola, Hymenoptera, Chalcidoidea, Aphelinidae.

Common name: None.

Geographical distribution: Probably a native of the Mediterranean basin; its distribution is now almost cosmopolitan.

Hosts: Several armored scale insects (Diaspididae), especially California red scale, Aonidiella aurantii (Maskell).

Economic importance: A member of a guild of parasitoids that attack the California red scale. In Israel and Cyprus A. chrysomphali occurs only along the coastal plain.

Morphology: The female is yellow, its size is from 0.6 to 1.0 mm.

Life cycle: Like other members of its genus, A. chrysomphali is an ectoparasitoid of armored scale insects. The 2nd-stage nymphs, young females and scale prepupae are attacked, but the ovipositing females are the preferred stage for parasitization. The eggs are deposited through the shield on the host’s body; due to the fact that when molting the shields of these scales adhere to their bodies, the ectoparasitoid can deposit only between molts. Its emerging larvae feed on the scales and prior to pupation they excrete their fecal matter in the shape of black pellets (”meconia”). The pupa is free, its eyes changing from colorless to red to green, providing an indication of age. The adult often emerges through an exit hole in the host’s shield, or by crawling out from underneath. Although obtained from several armored scale hosts, it is best known as a parasitoid of the California red scale. Aphytis chrysomphali is a uniparental thelytokous species (with rare males) and a voracious host feeder, killing more scales by this practice than by parasitization. It completes a cycle in a fortnight at 25Â°C, at which temperature each female produces about 25 offspring. It appears to be tolerant to low temperatures but susceptible to heat and aridity, attributes that could explain its prevalence along the coastal plain.

References

item.title: Aphytis hispanicus
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphytis hispanicus (Mercet)

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Holometabola, Hymenoptera, Chalcidoidea, Aphelinidae.

Geographical distribution: The Mediterranean Basin, Central America, Texas, California, Taiwan.

Hosts: Several armored scale insects (Diaspididae), especially chaff scale, Parlatoria pergandiiComstock and tropical grey chaff scale, Parlatoria cinereaHadden. In the laboratory the parasitoid can be reared on the latania scale, Hemiberlesia lataniae(Signoret).

Economic importance: A parasitoid of chaff scales.

Morphology: The female is yellow, its size being from 0.6 to 1.0 mm.

Life cycle: Like other members of its genus, Aphytis hispanicus is an ectoparasitoid of armored scale insects. The 2nd-stage nymphs, young females and scale prepupae are sometimes attacked, but the ovipositing females are the preferred stage for parasitization. The eggs are deposited through the shield on the host’s body; due to the fact that when molting the shields of these scales adhere to their bodies, the parasitoid can deposit only between molts. Its emerging larvae feed on the scales and prior to pupation they excrete their fecal matter in the shape of black pellets (”meconia”). The pupa is free, its eyes changing from colorless to red to green, providing an indication of its age. The adult often emerges through an exit hole in the shield, or by crawling out from underneath. A. hispanicus is a uniparental thelytokous species, requiring about a fortnight to complete a generation at 28Â°C, each female producing about 24 offspring. In the field this solitary parasitoid has two population peaks, in spring and in autumn, being rare during summer and winter. It attacks its chaff scale hosts mostly on the leaves, less on the fruit and very seldom on the wooden parts of the trees, and does not feed on its hosts.

References

item.title: Oncastichus goughi
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Oncastichus goughi Headrick and Lasalle

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Holometabola, Hymenoptera, Apocryta, Chalcidoidea, Eulophidae.

Common name: Geraldton wax wasp.

Geographical distribution: Australia, California and in Israel since the 1990âs.

Host plants: The cut-flower crop Chamelaucium uncinatum (Myrtaceae)

Morphology: The adult wasps are black, about 1-2 mm in length

Economic importance: A major pest of Geraldton wax, Chamelaucium uncinatum (Myrtaceae) (wax flower). It induces galls and plant deformations, rendering the cut-flower crop as well as the foliage unmarketable.

Life cycle: The eggs are placed within the host plant and the larvae develop in young leaves and stems, inducing the formation of galls and other deformations. Pupation takes place within the gall, the adult bores a round hole through which it emerges. Catches in traps suggest that the pest raises two annual, overlapping generations.

Management

Monitoring: Green and yellow sticky traps can be used to monitor the occurrence of the pest.

Cultural control: The early cultivars of Chamelaucium uncinatum that bear smaller leaves are less susceptible to the pest.

Chemical control: Avermectins and imidacloprids, applied as systemics greatly reduce the pestâs damage.

item.title: Phyllocnistis citrella
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Phyllocnistis citrella Stainton

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Holometabola, Lepidoptera, Gracillariidae

Common name: Citrus leafminer

Geographical distribution: The origin of this pest is in Southeast Asia. Now it occurs wherever citrus is grown; in the Middle East since 1994.

Host plants: Mainly plants of the family Rutaceae. Within that family, it is most often found on various species and varieties of citrus.

Symptoms: The mining of the larvae within young citrus leaves distorts them and destroys the epidermis (Figure 1),

and thus the leaf’s photosynthetic capability. Mature leaves are not attacked. Mining within the fruit’s peel, although uncommon (except for pummeloes), causes direct damage (Figure 2).

Economic importance: A major pest of citrus throughout its distribution. The main damage is to seedlings in nurseries, young trees (1-3 years old) and to the young growth after grafting. Fruit-bearing trees are seldom damaged.

Morphology: The adult is about 2-3 mm long, silvery-white with black spots, and four dark stripes on each forewing. The larvae are light-green in color, almost transparent, up to 3 mm in length (Figure3)

Life cycle: Each female deposits about 50-130 eggs, placing them on the very young leaves and the youngest twigs. The emerging larvae enter the leaves and burrow therein, forming uneven mines (Figure 1), where pupation takes place. The larvae have 4 instars: the 1st to 3rd instar larvae feed, whereas the 4th instar is spinning larva that does not feed. The pest may raise a generation in a fortnight at 25Â°C and long day conditions, thus completing several generations in a year. It has no diapause.

Phenology: Due to its specificity for citrus and preference for young leaves as oviposition sites, the phenology of the pest is determined by the host’s growth or flashing cycles. The first and main flash, in the spring, is rarely affected in Israel. This is due to the low winter temperatures and/or because of natural enemy activity in the former year. The mid-summer and late summer flashes, which in any case are usually smaller, may be more damaged by the pest.

Management:

Crop resistance: No species or varieties of citrus are clearly resistant to the pest.

Chemical control: As soon as the pest is first noted on young trees (1-3 years old) in the spring, they should be treated. This may include a spray with abamectin and a concurrent soil treatment with the systemic imidacloprid). An alternative is to brush the systemic acetamiprid on the trunks; the precise method is dependent on tree age and trunk diameter. Confidor and Mospilan can also be applied to control infestations that occur during later growth flashes. Fruit-bearing trees do not need to be treated.

Biological control: No indigenous natural enemies seem to have any effect on the pest. Three imported hymenopterous parasitoids usually control the citrus leafminer in Israel: Citrostichus phyllocnistoides (Narayan), Semielacher petiolatus (Girault) and Cirrospilus ingenuus Gahan.

item.title: Thaumetopoea pityocampa
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Thaumetopoea pityocampa (Denis & SchiffermÃ¼ller)

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Holometabola, Lepidoptera, Thaumetopoeidae.

Common name: Winter pine processionary moth.

Geographical distribution: The western Mediterranean region, reaching south-western Turkey in the Middle East, colonizing over 1,500,000 ha.

In the past the vicariants Thaumetopoea pityocampa and Thaumetopoea wilkinsoni Tams were often confused. A molecular study recently revealed differences between the two species, which became separated before the Quaternary ice ages. Commonwealth Institute of Entomology Map #366, 1977.

Host plants: Feeding of the pest is restricted to pines, such as Pinus nigra, P. brutia, P. sylvestris L, P. pinea P. halepensis and to Cedrus spp.

Economic importance: The larvae feed on the needles which then drop; saplings may be entirely defoliated, causing tree dieback and even death. Fourth- and fifth-instar larvae consume all the needles of pine trees, so that they to have been burned. The average decrease in annual diameter increment for Calabrian trees in damaged areas, compared with healthy trees, can reach about 22%.

The larvae are armed with stinging setae that break off easily and release a protein, thaumetopoein, which causes inflammations of eyes and of the respiratory system in humans and domestic animals, as well as allergies.

The moth is a relatively new pest in Turkey, whose emergence has been attributed to the intense cultivation of conifers for afforestation of degraded soils and as ornamentals, and the recent expansion of the pest to upper elevations and latitudes.

Morphology: The greyish adults bear transverse dark stripes and their heads are decorated with dense hairs. The young larvae are brown-yellow, becoming darker with each molt. All larvae bear red-brown tubercles with yellow-white detachable setae with hooked tips. The average weight of mature larvae is almost 0.80 g, and their average length 30 mm.

Life cycle: Thaumetopoea pityocampa is univoltine. Adults emerge and fly in August, laying eggs in September; the larvae hatch by the end of that month and the next (October). They form processions as they crawl along pine branches to find feeding sites and then rest in nests; an average nest holding about 210 larvae. They pass through five instars, pupating in the soil during May, June and July. Pine secondary plant constituents seem to determine the pest’s host selection processes.

Management

Chemical control

Organophosphates were formerly applied against the pest. Steam-distilled wood sulfate turpentine was the best of several essential plant oils tried in Turkey to control the pest.

Preparations of Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) may control the pest but two applications are required for satisfactory control. This is the result of the prolonged, month-long emergence of the vulnerable young larval instars, whose late members avoid the treatment, which does not persist that long on the needles.

Biological control: In Turkey the pest is attacked by several natural enemies, the more common being the hymenopterous egg parasitoids Ooencyrtus pityocampae (Mercet) (Encyrtidae) and Eutetrastichus (Baryscapus) servadeii (Dom.) (Eulophidae). The former parasitized eggs placed near the top of the batches, whereas the latter was found mainly in eggs near the base of the batches. All egg parasitoids together reduced hatching rate to 50.7-65.6%.

item.title: Thaumetopoea wilkinsoni
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Thaumetopoea wilkinsoni Tams

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Holometabola, Lepidoptera, Thaumetopoeidae.

Common name: Cyprus processionary caterpillar.

Geographical distribution: Cyprus, Israel, Jordan and Lebanon.

The vicariants Thaumetopoea wilkinsoni and Thaumetopoea pityocampa (Denis and SchiffermÃ¼ller) were often confused in the past. However, a recent molecular study showed clear differences between the two species, which became separated before the Quaternary ice ages. Thaumetopoea wilkinsoni is restricted to the Middle East, whereas T. pityocampa is a more western species.

Host plants: Feeding of the pest is restricted to pines (Pinus spp.). In the Middle East young P. eldarica trees are preferred to P. brutia and P. halepensis.

Economic importance: The larvae feed on the needles, which causes their shedding; saplings may entirely be defoliated, causing die back and even (in dry years) tree death. Larger trees may recover, although totally defoliated branches can still be seen. The external parts of the trees, especially young ones, are usually preferred. The larvae are armed with stinging setae that easily break off and release a protein, thaumetopoein, which causes inflammations of eyes and of the respiratory system in humans and domestic animals, as well as allergies.

Large-scale reforestation programs with pines undertaken in Cyprus and Israel have increased the importance of the pest.

Morphology: The brownish adults, whose length is 17-22 mm, bear transverse dark stripes and their bodies are decorated with dense hairs. The young larvae are brown-yellow, becoming darker with each molt. At maturity they are almost black and attain a size of 40 mm. All larvae bear tubercles with yellow-white detachable setae with hooked tips.

Life cycle: The pest is univoltine. Adults emerge in the autumn and lay their eggs in early winter. Each female lays many eggs, arranging them in rows around pine needles and covering them with reddish scales. The larvae emerge after 6-7 weeks and immediately form processions that march off to seek food. The young larvae feed only on the needles’ epidermis, but later stages consume entire needles. After a few days of feeding the larvae form a temporary communal nest, moving to another site as they crawl on to look for fresh needles. Larval development lasts 4-6 months, pupation taking place in the soil and takes about 5 months.

Management

Cultural control: Mass male trapping is feasible with the pheromone pityolure.

Chemical control: Stem injections with an organophosphate bring about 100% mortality, as do implants of similar pesticides.

Biological control: Various stages of the pest are attacked by several natural enemies, the more common being the hymenopterous egg parasitoids Ooencyrtus pityocampae (Mercet) (Encyrtidae) and Eutetrastichus servadeii (Dom.) (Eulophidae). Their overall effect on the pest appears to be negligible.

item.title: Zeuzera pyrina
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Zeuzera pyrina (L.)

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Holometabola, Lepidoptera, Cossidae.

Common name: Leopard moth.

Geographical distribution: Europe, North and South Africa, Japan, North America, Mediterranean region. Distribution Maps of Plant Pests, No. 314, Commonwealth Institute of Entomology. 1973.

Host plants: Polyphagous, preferring soft-wood trees, in the Middle East occurring mostly on apple, olive, pear, plum, pomegranate and about 150 other tree species.

Economic importance: A single young larva may cause the death of thin branches, by withering or breaking. Although olives are less susceptible, the tendency of the moth to remain on the same hosts results in several pest generations developing there, causing considerable damage to the trees, which become weakened.

Morphology: The adult moth is whitish and covered by numerous dark-bluish spots when developing within apple trees, whereas those from olives have pinkish wings with greenish dotes. The body is darkish with white hairs. At rest the wings are folded along the body, which is 25-30 mm long. The males are smaller (20 mm long). The larva is dark-yellow with black dorsal tubercles, About 50-55 mm long.

Life cycle: The moths occur in the orchards from May to November, dependent upon temperatures, host plant and plant protection practices. A female lives about one week, depositing 100-300 eggs on the bark, mostly on the tree from which it had emerged, or nearby. The emerging larvae bore into young twigs, often at the leaf bases, bringing about the withering on a leaf growing underneath. The larvae then move into elder, thicker branches wherein it continues to borrow into the wood, pushing out its brownish frass and completing its development there. The pattern of the excavated tunnels differs between trees. In hosts like deciduous fruit trees, the tunnels are straight, whereas in other trees, like olives, the tunnels may be circular or sinuous. Prior to pupation the mature larva bores an emergence hole near the original point of ingress, and seals it by a thin membrane. The young adults break through and emerge. The pest completes a single annual generation in the Middle East.

Management

Monitoring: Light traps have been used in the past, but were supplemented by male mating disruption traps, placed during spring on the trees, to serve as an early warning system. Another method is to observe the occurrence of âflag leavesâ, the withering leaves at the bases of thin branches infested by the young larvae.

Cultural contro: In the past thin wires were inserted through the frass into the burrows, or pesticides were thus introduced. These are time consuming methods and probably suitable only in instances of low infestations. More recently by pheromone threads (650 per hectare) is being used, as it controls the pest on olives during most of the season,.

Chemical control: Organophosphates are used when necessary, but may only be applied against the exposed adults, and cannot be used during harvest. IGRs have also been successfully applied.

Biological control: The parasitic hymenopterous Elachertus nigritulusZetterstedt, (Eulophidae) has been mass reared from leopard moth larvae, but its effect on the pestâs damage is not known.
